feed.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin

entry.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
The discussion between Boris Nagaev and Jameson Lopp delves into the complexities of securing Bitcoin against potential quantum computing threats. They explore a thought experiment which contrasts the approaches of freezing vulnerable Bitcoin outputs versus outright confiscation. The proposed strategy involves limiting transactions from quantum-vulnerable outputs (such as those from Pay-to-PubKey, P2PK) to only allow them to be spent on similarly vulnerable outputs. This method does not confiscate the assets but imposes restrictions that effectively segregate the Bitcoin ecosystem into two tiers: quantum-vulnerable and quantum-resistant coins.
This bifurcation raises significant concerns regarding the practicality and value of quantum-vulnerable bitcoins. Questions arise about the willingness of miners to process transactions involving these vulnerable coins, the likelihood of exchanges accepting them, and the overall trust in their security. The intrinsic value of quantum-vulnerable bitcoins could plummet due to the heightened risk of theft by entities wielding quantum computing capabilities. Such a scenario would not only degrade these coins to an inflationary mechanism favoring quantum computer owners but also threaten the integrity and value of the entire Bitcoin network by introducing rampant inflation via these attacks.
Furthermore, Lopp highlights a possible mitigation technique for protecting certain vulnerable outputs through BIP-39 HD Seed proofs, which could establish ownership without exposing these assets to quantum theft. This approach seeks to minimize the confiscatory impact by preventing theft, thus safeguarding the property rights of the affected coin holders. Through this nuanced examination, the dialogue underscores the critical need for protective measures that balance security enhancements with the foundational principles of property and value within the Bitcoin ecosystem.
